page.title: 02HISTORY OF RIPPINGALE LINCS
page.content: The name{Rippingale}is of Celtic origin Ri(elevated) Apen(river) Cal(forest) and was first mentioned in 806.Effigies can be seen in the 13thC. church of the Goband,Marmyon and Brownlowe families.Before the Church School was built,in 1855,for the sum of Â£400,a Dame School was held alongside the church organ.There were once ten public houses,including The Mill,The Angel and The Strawyard Tavern;two bakehouses,a blacksmith's forge and a workhouse.Many of the cottages were thatched.In Doctor's Lane there were limekilns and brickyards.The Pinfold,now a recently built estate of bungalows,was used for straying cattle and a fee had to be paid to reclaim them.Among the local tradesmen were a molecatcher,a carrier a scissor grinder and a woolgatherer!
